user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 msecs)
{
    struct timespec                     ts;
    int                                 result;
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    /*
     ** Compute an absolute time for the delay
     */
    OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(msecs, &ts);

    if (sem_timedwait(&impl->id, &ts) == 0)
    {
        result = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else if (errno == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        result = OS_SEM_TIMEOUT;
    }
    else
    {
        /* unspecified failure */
        result = OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
void OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(uint32 msecs, struct timespec *tm)
{
    clock_gettime(CLOCK_REALTIME, tm);

    /* add the delay to the current time */
    tm->tv_sec += (time_t)(msecs / 1000);
    /* convert residue ( msecs )  to nanoseconds */
    tm->tv_nsec += (msecs % 1000) * 1000000L;

    if (tm->tv_nsec >= 1000000000L)
    {
        tm->tv_nsec -= 1000000000L;
        tm->tv_sec++;
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any code fragments that are provably unreachable and therefore that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. Rationale:

- The conditional chain in OS_CountSemTimedWait_Impl is reachable in all its parts depending on sem_timedwait() outcome: the success branch (return 0), the ETIMEDOUT branch (sem_timedwait() fails and errno==ETIMEDOUT), and the final else (sem_timedwait() fails with errno other than ETIMEDOUT). None of these branches is syntactically or semantically impossible.

- The call to OS_Posix_CompAbsDelayTime(msecs, &ts) is executed unconditionally and its internal code is reachable: clock_gettime() executes, the arithmetic that adds seconds and nanoseconds can lead to the tm->tv_nsec >= 1e9 condition (when the residue pushes it over the boundary), so the normalization branch is reachable.

- The macro expansion for impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token) expands to &OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(*token))], which is equivalent to &OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(token)] — this is valid and does not introduce unreachable code. (Index-out-of-range would be undefined behavior but is not the same as unreachable code.)

- There are no early returns, conditional compilation blocks, or constant expressions that would make any code path permanently unreachable.

Because none of the code constructs are syntactically impossible or statically unreachable, there are no fragments to report for further investigation under Rule 2.1.
